title: Typographic Budapest?
content:
I will be heading off to [Budapest](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014205157/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Budapest) for two weeks and I thought I would solicit some suggestions about typo-interesting places to see. Or any places, really, above and beyond the typical tourist hot-spots that people here have found interesting.

Thanks!

K.
author: Kristina Drake

do the thermal baths.. they're a great experience.

Széchenyi baths are great:  
 [http://cityguide.budapestrooms.com/sights/sights5.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014205157/http:/cityguide.budapestrooms.com/sights/sights5.htm "http://cityguide.budapestrooms.com/sights/sights5.htm")

At the second-hand bookshops ask for the books designed by [Tibor Szántó](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014205157/http:/www.bestwebbuys.com/Tibor_Szanto-author.html?isrc=b-compare-author), the great Hungarian typographer--printed in the 1960s and 1970s; the better ones were published by Helikon Kiadó and Európa Könyvkiadó. Some of them are truly superb.

Take a trip to Gyoma, the home of the [Kner family](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014205157/http:/www.gyomaikner.hu/eng/muzeum_2.html). The Kners owned a printshop there, and made themselves a name in the world of private press printing with their exquisite little books, very tastefully typeset, illustrated and decorated. The shop was still active in the 1970s; I remember how impressed I was by the quality of its presswork, binding, and the fact that some books manufactured at Kner Nyomda were printed on a special, watermarked stock, which used to be produced in small quantities for those limited editions.

[Moholy-Nagy Művészeti Egyetem](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014205157/http:/w2.mome.hu/) (Moholy-Nagy University of Art and Design, formerly known as Magyar Iparművészeti Főiskola) could be worth a trip. It used to be a pretty good school for graphic and typographic design. Many excellent Hungarian design professionals are MIF graduates, and some teach there.

For additional information on Hungarian typography see a very good listing offered by [Luc Devroye](http://web.archive.org/web/20131014205157/http:/cg.scs.carleton.ca/~luc/hungary.html).
